Award.AwardTitle: Bulk Turbulence in Polymer Solutions: Beyond Friction Drag Reduction

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Ouellette, Nicholas
Proposal Number: 1436423

The goal of the proposed research is to explore the effects of adding polymers in the bulk of turbulent flows. When small amounts of additives, including long-chain polymers, surfactants, or microbubbles, are added to a turbulent flow, the structure and dynamics of the flow can change dramatically. The most celebrated effect of additives is skin-friction drag reduction: tiny amounts of polymers or surfactants can reduce the drag in a turbulent wall-bounded flow by up to 80%. After years of research, the scientific community is beginning to reach consensus on the fundamental physics of this drag reduction. Skin friction, however, is only a part of the total fluid drag experienced by ships or other objects immersed in a fluid. Separation of the boundary layer and the dynamics of turbulent wakes lead to energy losses that frequently dominate the frictional losses over the object. Understanding how additives affect these other types of drag requires the study of the modification of bulk turbulence, far from any walls, in the presence of additives. Although it is known that bulk turbulence does change with additives, current models cannot explain the experimental observations. The research proposed here will address this gap via detailed experimental measurements of bulk turbulence in polymer solutions. In terms of education and outreach, a new module for an undergraduate laboratory class based on non-Newtonian turbulence, will be developed. In addition, the PI will develop movies about the research results that will be displayed in an on-campus coffee shop and on YouTube, and will participate in K-12 outreach via a local science-fair program.

The primary goal of the project is to understand what aspects of the modification of the turbulent dynamics by polymers is dependent on the presence of a wall, and what aspects are more universal. To address this question, the rates of energy injection, scale-to-scale transfer, and dissipation will be measured as a function of polymer concentration, and modification to the decay of turbulence will be studied. In addition, measurements will be made of the spatial structure of the flow, in order to test the common hypothesis that polymers interact with and suppress small-scale vorticity. The experimental measurements will be made in the Lagrangian framework, using Lagrangian particle tracking, where a multicamera stereoimaging setup is used to follow the motion of small tracer particles in three dimensions and in time as they are advected by the flow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulent flows are ubiquitous in both natural and engineered systems; unless great care is taken, the typical state of fluid flow is most situations is turbulent. Nevertheless, understanding the nature of turbulence and predicting how turbulent flows will behave in practical situations remain a grand challenge problems in science and engineering. 

The situation becomes even more complicated when the material properties of the fluid itself are changed. For example, when small amounts of polymers are added to the fluid, the dynamics of the flow can change significantly. The most celebrated effect of additives is skin-friction drag reduction: it has been known since the 1940s that tiny amounts of polymers or surfactants can reduce the drag in a wall-bounded turbulent flow by up to 80%. After many decades of research, the scientific community is beginning to reach consensus on the physics controlling this drag reduction. But new experiments in the past decade have begun to reveal that turbulence is significantly changed by additives well away from any walls that cause drag, meaning that drag reduction is only part of the story. 

The primary goal of this project was to understand what aspects of turbulence modification by polymers are preserved in the bulk of the flow far from any walls, and what new phenomena may appear there. To achieve this goal, we conducted detailed experiments in a highly turbulent laboratory flow using water with a range of concentrations of dissolved polymers. We also developed new ways of analyzing the physics of turbulent flows that will help to elucidate the modifications introduced by the polymer molecules.

We obtained a rich data set of fully developed turbulence in water with small amounts (from 1 part per million by weight to 20) of dissolved polyacrylamide using high-speed particle tracking in a laboratory swirling flow. Using this data set, we tested different models of how the polymers interact with turbulence. In particular, we compared our results with the recent “elastic energy flux balance” model that is based on balancing the rate of turbulent energy transfer through the turbulent inertial range and the rate at which elastic energy is stored and released by the polymer molecules, and which has been argued to be superior to earlier models. To test it, we computed a number of different turbulence statistics (many of which had never been measured in polymer solutions): the Eulerian velocity structure functions, the Eulerian acceleration correlation functions, the Lagrangian velocity structure functions, and the relative dispersion of fluid-element pairs. To compare our Lagrangian statistics with the model predictions, we extended the model into the time domain by introducing the concept that a turbulent eddy must persist for a finite amount of time to stretch a polymer molecule to a given length.

Surprisingly, we found that our results were only partially in agreement with the model predictions. Instead of collapsing all of our data onto a single master curve, the scaling suggested by the model produced two distinct families of curves, one at low concentrations and one at high concentrations. We hypothesized that the two curves are a result of the specific parameter range we studied, which was different from what was investigated in previous work. Specifically, we suggested that we may have observed a transition from independent to interacting polymer chains, which can be tested in future experiments.

We also used our data to evaluate the longstanding hypothesis that polymers modify the precise balance between strain and rotation that appears to be a universal feature of turbulent flows. This hypothesis has been very difficult to test, since the very high spatial resolution needed to measure these quantities directly is nearly impossible to achieve. Instead, we introduced the idea of using inertial particles (that is, heavy particles that do not follow the fluid flow) as probes of the turbulence structure. It is well known that such particles tend to avoid highly rotational regions in the flow and instead accumulate in strongly straining regions. Thus, if the polymers were to change the balance of strain and rotation, there would be a signature in the clustering statistics of the inertial particles. When testing this idea experimentally, we indeed found such a signature that increased with polymer concentration, thus validating this hypothesis about the effects of polymers on the spatial structure of the flow. Moreover, we were again able to use the elastic energy flux balance model to predict how this modification should vary with the polymer concentration, and showed that our experimental results were well captured by this prediction.

Finally, we also developed new analysis methods to study the mechanisms responsible for energy transfer from scale to scale in turbulence. These techniques reveal new details of this process, which is thought to be of fundamental importance in turbulence, and provide a baseline for understanding how polymers modify the flow.
